DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
FOMC

Fed held Funds Target Rate at 1.50%-1.75% as expected, with the decision via unanimous vote. (Newswires)
Fed stated that inflation has moved close to its “symmetric” inflation target of 2% and is expected to 'run near' that level over the medium term. Fed stated employment growth has been strong on average and growing moderately, while it added that risks to the economic outlook appear to be roughly balanced. Furthermore, the Fed now characterises inflation as “moved close” to 2% (previously it was described as “continued to run below 2%”).

Note: There was an initial but delayed dovish reaction to the statement with the “symmetric” reference to its inflation target eventually interpreted as the idea that the Fed would be prepared to allow an overshoot of inflation without taking aggressive action to rein in price pressures. However, the dovish reaction seen in the greenback was then fully pared as participants then digested another crucial tweak in which the Fed now characterises inflation as “moved close” to 2% (previously it was described as “continued to run below 2%”).

US

Trump Legal Advisor Giuliani said US President Trump and his lawyers are inclined to go ahead with the Special Counsel Mueller Interview and that Mueller interview would not occur until beginning of summer. (Newswires)

White House said details have not been finalized regarding agreement for Brazil to avoid steel and aluminium tariffs, while it added President Trump will consider re-imposing tariffs if the agreement with Brazil is not finalized soon. (Newswires)

US ADP National Employment (Apr) 204k vs. Exp. 200k (Prev. 241k, Rev. 228k). (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

Emini futures in overnight trade slipped after news that Trump could potentially face a subpoena if he refused to testify as part of the Russian probe. But futures deviated little from the 2650-mark pre-Fed. However, following the Fed, equities caught a slight bid, albeit temporary, and resumed the slide heading into the close. Meanwhile, earnings today were dominated by Apple (AAPL) who reported an EPS of $2.73 on Tuesday, higher than the expected $2.69; revenue was a touch light coming in at 61.14bln against expected $61.2bln. However, shares surged after market following the announcement of $100bln share repurchase programme and a dividend increase of 16% to $0.73. In terms of unit sales, iPhone sales were a slight miss at 52.2mln, against the expected 53mln whilst iPads and Macs slightly exceeded expectations. Apple led the DJI for Wednesday’s session, Gilead (GILD) reported after market on Tuesday where EPS and revenues both missed analyst expectations which pressured the NDX, GILD were the underperformer in the index. SPX -0.72% at 2635, NDX -0.56% at 6644, DJI -0.73% at 23923.

Treasuries were higher on Wednesday after the Treasury’s increased auction sizes announced at Quarterly Refunding weren’t as aggressive as some had anticipated (feared). The package for May was $73bln (versus $66bln previously). Treasury sees the sizes of the 2- and 3-year note auctions being raised by $1bln per month (vs $2bln in Q1), and in addition, it will increase the auction size of the next 2-year FRN auction by USD 1bln in May. The Treasury will also raise the auction sizes by $1bln for each of the next 5-, 7-, and 10-year notes and the 30-year bond auctions in May. It also intends to introduce a new 2-month bill later this calendar year, and is evaluating whether to add a second new 5-year TIPS security to the annual TIPS calendar. Treasuries found buyers after the announcement, before easing a touch heading into the FOMC decision; after the FOMC was interpreted as dovish, the curve found more buyers, leaving yields around c. 2bps lower across the curve at settlement; 2s30s, 5s30 and 2s10s, 5s10s widened by a modest c.2bps. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 4+ ticks higher at 119-16+.

subject: US MARKET WRAP 2 May 2018: Fed unchanged, crude looks through inventory data, ADP in line.
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, DXY up, Crude up.
* REAR-VIEW: Fed on hold as expected, tweaks statement; ADP inline.
* AHEAD: After-market earnings; TSLA, KHC, ISRX, AIG, MET, PRU; Thurs earnings: DWDP, K, ADS GY, BAYN GY. Flash Apr EZ CPI, ECB speak (Constancio, Praet, Coeure); Non-MFG ISM; Norges Bank.

 

* FEDERAL RESERVE: The Fed kept rates unchanged at 1.50-1.75%, as expected. The statement, however, saw a few crucial tweaks: the Fed now characterises inflation as “moved close” to 2% (previously it was described as “continued to run below 2%”), and additionally, it added word “symmetric” with regards to its inflation target, which traders eventually interpreted as the idea that the Fed would be prepared to allow an overshoot of inflation without taking aggressive action to rein in price pressures, and subsequently (in a, once again, delayed reaction) the market’s reply was dovish.  

* DATA: Ahead of Friday’s payrolls data, ADP reported that 204K jobs were added to the US economy in April, more-or-less in-line against an expected 198K. Pantheon Macroeconomics noted that the numbers tend to be less responsive to weather effects than the official payroll figure, since it is based on macro data, as well as data collected from firms that use ADP’s payroll services. Nonetheless, Pantheon does not expect a significant effect attributable to weather in April and thus should provide a positive signal ahead of the official payroll figure on Friday. Once again, analysts warned that the ADP data is not a definitive guide to the official payrolls figures, and Capital Economics says that recently it has been even less useful. Over the previous six months, the average difference between the ADP and BLS measures of private employment growth has been as high as 80,000.

* CHINA TRADE: ahead of the Bejing trade talks meeting which will be attended by US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin, NEC Director Kudlow, President Assistant Advisor Navarro and US Trade Representative Lighthizer, China commented that it is unrealistic to expect one meeting to solve problems; Earlier, a Chinese official stated the country will not give into threats from the US on trade while the US is considering curbs on Chinese telecom firms over national security concerns.

* NAFTA: Mexico's Deputy Economy Minister Baker sees a 80% chance for NAFTA deal being agreed this month.

* BREXIT: The Brexit customs partnership model has been rejected by the "war cabinet,” according to the BBC; it was one of two models proposed by the government and would remove the need for new customs checks at the border, with the other option a streamlined customs arrangement which would minimise checks using technology and trusted trader schemes. Following the news, there were reports that UK PM May told a Minister that the UK will leave the Customs Unions. Elsewhere, the House of Lords once again defeated the government, backing powers to prevent a hard border in Ireland; the defeat was the government’s tenth defeat in Brexit legislation.

* ECB SPEAK: ECB’s Weidmann (Hawk) stated market expectations for first hike around mid-2019 is not unrealistic, adding that monetary normalisation will take some time, and it is important not to unnecessarily postpone the beginning of tightening. He also mentioned that worries about approaching the end of the Eurozone’s economic upswing are exaggerated while the current guidance on timing of the first hike is quite vague.

* RIKSBANK: Riksbank Governor Ingves said if Swedish rates rise too quickly, the SEK would strengthen and inflation will likely fall. He added that the inflation/currency impact of a rate rise would be a “difficult trade off” and also said that he believes the SEK will continue to strengthen. Elsewhere, he said supervisors have a “weak hand” to deal with overheating housing market, and also argued that there was still scope for the Riksbank to use monetary tools to help stoke inflation and support the economy.

* EQUITIES: SPX -0.72% at 2635, NDX -0.56% at 6644, DJI -0.73% at 23923 SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals: -0.89%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: -0.71%, Energy: +0.39%, Financials: -1.44%, Health Care: -2.00%, Industrials: -0.93%, Materials: -0.42%, Technology: -0.02%, Telecoms: -1.76%, Utilities: -0.14%.

* Emini futures in overnight trade slipped after news that Trump could potentially face a subpoena if he refused to testify as part of the Russian probe. But futures deviated little from the 2650-mark pre-Fed. However, following the Fed, equities caught a slight bid, albeit temporary, and resumed the slide heading into the close.

* Earnings today were dominated by Apple (AAPL) who reported an EPS of $2.73 on Tuesday, higher than the expected $2.69; revenue was a touch light coming in at 61.14bln against expected $61.2bln. However, shares surged after market following the announcement of $100bln share repurchase programme and a dividend increase of 16% to $0.73. In terms of unit sales, iPhone sales were a slight miss at 52.2mln, against the expected 53mln whilst iPads and Macs slightly exceeded expectations. Apple led the DJI for Wednesday’s session, Gilead (GILD) reported after market on Tuesday where EPS and revenues both missed analyst expectations which pressured the NDX, GILD were the underperformer in the index.

* M&A news today focused around Xerox (XRX) which reached an agreement with Carl Icahn and Darwin Deason over the proposed merger with Fujifilm, XRX CEO is to resign and is going to be replaced by Icahn Enterprises CEO, Keith Cozza, as well as the appointment of 6 new board members. During Wednesday trade source reports suggested Apollo Global Management (APO) approached XRX showing acquisition interest.

* Late trade saw source reports that Amazon (AMZN) is to offer retailers discounts if they use Amazon Pay, this had a knock-on effect for PayPal (PYPL) who spiked to fresh lows and saw intraday declines of over 4%. Mastercard (MA), Square (SQ), Visa (V) and American Express (AXP) were all hit as well, however not to the same extent as PYPL.

* CRUDE: WTI settles $0.68 higher at $67.93/bbl; Brent settles $0.23 higher at $73.36/bbl. Crude shrugged off bearish API (after-market Tuesday) and DOE data on Wednesday (Crude +6.218M vs. exp. 0.739M, crude production +0.31% to 10.619mln bpd, Cushing +0.416mln, Distillate -3.9mln vs. exp. -1.360mln, Gasoline +1.17mln vs. exp.  -0.587mln, refining utilisation +0.3% vs. exp. 0.6%.) Analysts suggest that it signals that the market’s attention is firmly fixed on the geopolitical situation in Iran, where the US will decide by 12/May whether to pull out of the Iran nuclear accord and reinstate sanctions (the consensus view is that this would drive crude higher as supply tightens, and Iran is hindered from raising foreign investment to finance boosting capacity).

* Saudi Arabia’s energy minister again said the OPEC+ supply cut pact will run through the end of 2018. Separately, an IMF official said Saudi Arabia needs oil prices around $85 to $87/bbl to balance its budget. In Russia, May oil production was reported to be in line with the April data around 10.97mln BPD, an 11-month high. 

* Elsewhere in the energy complex, Colonial said it was investigating an issue on lines 3, 4, 25 and 27, providing few details, sending RBOB higher (The Colonial Pipeline delivers more than 100mln gallons of refined products daily).

* TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 4+ ticks higher at 119-16+. Treasuries were higher on Wednesday after the Treasury’s increased auction sizes announced at Quarterly Refunding weren’t as aggressive as some had anticipated (feared). The package for May was $73bln (versus $66bln previously). Treasury sees the sizes of the 2- and 3-year note auctions being raised by $1bln per month (vs $2bln in Q1), and in addition, it will increase the auction size of the next 2-year FRN auction by USD 1bln in May. The Treasury will also raise the auction sizes by $1bln for each of the next 5-, 7-, and 10-year notes and the 30-year bond auctions in May. It also intends to introduce a new 2-month bill later this calendar year, and is evaluating whether to add a second new 5-year TIPS security to the annual TIPS calendar. Treasuries found buyers after the announcement, before easing a touch heading into the FOMC decision; after the FOMC was interpreted as dovish, the curve found more buyers, leaving yields around c. 2bps lower across the curve at settlement; 2s30s, 5s30 and 2s10s, 5s10s widened by a modest c.2bps.

* FOREX: DXY: The index and broad Dollar has broken out of earlier tight confines to the upside and consolidate above 92.65 pre-Fed. However, the DXY slipped after the FOMC decision, with the statement interpreted as dovish, and traders booking some profits on the stellar gains printed by the Greenback in recent sessions.

* AUD, NZD: The only 2 G10 currencies to weather the latest bout of all-round buck buying, and then only just as AUDUSD and NZDUSD cling to positive territory on the day slightly above 0.7500 and 0.7000 respectively.

* GBP: Another relative outperformer after some rare good news on the data front, with April’s construction PMI beating expectations after Tuesday’s manufacturing miss, and ahead of tomorrow’s services survey. Cable did fall sub-1.36 pre-Fed after the buck was bought in early US trade and extended losses in late trade post-Fed, focus now on the 200 DMA at 1.3536.

EURGBP was capped at 0.88 for most of the session, but did find ground above it as the US day neared an end.

* CHF, JPY: Both remain weaker against the dollar despite late USD selling post-Fed. Earlier in the session EURUSD lost the 1.20 level and falling to lows above 1.1950; the next support to the downside is 1.1936 (Fib), then the 1.1916 YTD base before 1.1900. USDJPY broke 110.00 very slightly, though couldn’t hold onto gains at those lofty levels.

* CAD: USDCAD did regain the 1.2850 pivot amidst less positive NAFTA and tariff developments, and was consolidating are the level as we moved towards the close. MXN was also hit for similar reasons,

*TRY: Ratings cut woes weighing heavily on the Lira as USDTRY rebounds towards highs within a broad 4.0000-4.2000 range.

*SEK: The Krona depreciated further to circa 10.6750 vs the Eur amidst comments from Riksbank chief Ingves underlining that hiking rates too early risks too much SEK strength and downside inflation pressure.

* COMING-UP: Norges Bank will publish its monetary policy decision at 09:00 BST /10.00 CET on May 3rd; it is expected to keep rates unchanged at 0.50% on Thursday, but is likely to signal its hiking cycle will start after summer. No post-meeting press conference, or Monetary Policy Report. To download the report, please click here.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Greenback geared up for FOMC recharge, or retribution?
content:
DXY

The index and broad Dollar has broken out of earlier tight confines to the upside as the clock ticks down to the Fed’s latest rate announcement and accompanying policy statement, with the DXY just eclipsing the previous 2018 high (92.640). However, the question remains whether the FOMC fuels the latest rally or whether the Usd buying is premature and stalls or reverses after the event. Chart-wise, the 92.515 Fib needs to hold for the DXY to maintain bullish momentum towards the next big figure.

AUD/NZD

The only 2 G10 currencies to weather the latest bout of all round buck buying, and then only just as Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd cling to positive territory on the day around 0.7500 and 0.7000 respectively.

GBP

Another relative outperformer after some rare good news on the UK front as April’s construction PMI beat consensus after Tuesday’s manufacturing miss and ahead of tomorrow’s services survey. Cable remains above 1.3600, but some distance off 1.3650+ recovery highs, while Eur/Gbp remains capped under 0.8800 after choppy trade either side.

EUR/CAD/CHF/JPY

All ending Wednesday’s session, or rather approaching the Fed weaker vs the Usd having held recovery gains at one stage, with Eur/Usd losing 1.2000 and hitting fresh cycle lows around 1.1965. Nearest technical support seen at 1.1936 (Fib), then the 1.1916 ytd base before 1.1900. Usd/Cad is back above the 1.2850 pivot amidst less positive NAFTA and tariff developments, that have also hit the MXN for obvious reasons, while Usd/Chf and Usd/Jpy are retesting resistance and offers ahead of parity and 110.00.

TRY  

Ratings cut woes weighing heavily on the Lira as Usd/Try rebounds towards highs within a broad 4.0000-4.2000 range.

SEK

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 2nd May 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European bourses higher, tech sector leads following Apple’s earnings yesterday
  • The Greenback has eased off best levels across the board awaiting more fundamental direction from the FOMC later today
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US ADP, FOMC, DoEs, US refunding and a slew of speakers

 

ASIA-PAC

Asia equity markets eventually saw a broad risk-averse tone despite initially trading mixed throughout most the session following a similar close on Wall St. where stocks rebounded from the initial data-triggered selling pressure and the Nasdaq outperformed in anticipation of Apple earnings. The tech giant eventually reported a beat on EPS, announced a USD 100bln share repurchase authorization and raised dividends by 16%, although it slightly missed on revenue and iPhone sales; shares were higher by around 5% after-market which fuelled further upside in Nasdaq 100 futures to above 6700. US equity futures have since pulled-back from highs amid a bout of selling following reports that Special Counsel Mueller suggested the possibility of a subpoena if President Trump refuses to speak to investigators, although the pressure was suppressed shortly after it was determined this was from a meeting with Trump lawyers back in March. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) traded mixed as earnings dictated price action. Shanghai Comp. (flat) and Hang Seng (-0.3%) traded subdued despite initial gains in mainland on return from the extended weekend as it took its first opportunity to react to better than expected Chinese Official Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMI data. However, the picture then gradually deteriorated following the Caixin Manufacturing PMI which also topped estimates but showed Export Orders shrank for the first time since November 2016. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful amid similar price action in T-notes and as stocks took much of the focus, while the results of an enhanced-liquidity for 2yr-20yr also failed to spur demand.

Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI (Apr) 51.1 vs. Exp. 50.9 (Prev. 51.0). (Newswires)

PBoC injected CNY 200bln via 7-day reverse repos for a net neutral position due to maturing repos. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3670 (Prev. 6.3393); weakest fix since January 25th.

New Zealand Employment Change (Q1) Q/Q 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.5%). (Newswires)

New Zealand Employment Change (Q1) Y/Y 3.1% vs. Exp. 3.3% (Prev. 3.7%)

New Zealand Unemployment Rate (Q1) 4.4% vs. Exp. 4.4% (Prev. 4.5%)

 

EU/UK/US

UK PM May is expected to back EU ‘customs partnership’, according to press reports. (FT) However, there were separate reports that UK PM May was warned by 60 Conservative MPs a post-Brexit customs partnership with the EU will result to a collapse of the government. (Telegraph)

A majority of Italian Democratic Party leaders oppose a Salvini or Di Maio-led government. Italian President Mattarella wants a new government in order to pass 2019 budget and rules out June elections. 5 Star Movement leader Di Maio said a government is not possible with the centre right. (ANSA/Newswires)

EZ Markit Manufacturing Final PMI (Apr) 56.2 vs. Exp. 56.0 (Prev. 56.0) (Newswires)

EZ GDP Flash Prelim QQ (Q1) 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.6%, Rev. 0.7%)

EZ Unemployment Rate (Mar) 8.5% vs. Exp. 8.5% (Prev. 8.5%)

 

CENTRAL BANKS

BoC Governor Poloz said if NAFTA gets resolved, expect sentiment to improve but need to wait and see data before changing inflation outlook. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European markets have returned on an upbeat tone (Eurostoxx +0.4%) with all major bourses in the green following mass closures in the region yesterday. Germany’s DAX 30 is outperforming its peers after breaching its 200DMA to the upside. All sectors are firmly in the green with outperformance in materials as miners are lifted amid higher copper prices. The tech sector is feeling a boost following Apple’s earnings post-market yesterday with the likes of Infineon (+3.4%) and STMicroelectronics (+4.9%) at the top of their respective indices. On the downside, earnings dampened the likes of Paddy Power Betfair (-5.9%), Swisscom (-3.1%) and Direct Line Insurance (-3.2%).

 

FX

USD

The Greenback has eased off best levels across the board awaiting more fundamental direction from the FOMC later today, but figuratively speaking the next major move may well depend on several big figures that have been tried and tested, but not yet breached. In terms of the Dollar index, a base does appear to be forming at 92.000 after several approaches towards the 92.640 ytd peak and a rebound in US Treasury yields is supportive, albeit partly supply-related ahead of the Quarterly Refunding. Technically, 92.515 is a key Fib for the DXY that has yet to be cleared convincingly.

AUD/NZD

The biggest beneficiaries of a pause in the Greenback’s advance, but in truth largely due to the fact that both antipodeans have borne the brunt of losses when trading below 0.7500 and 0.7000 respectively. No real positive momentum for the Kiwi from rather indifferent NZ jobs data overnight, but Nzd/Usd has rebounded relatively firmly above the big figure again, as Aud/Usd retains its round number status and the cross straddles 1.0700.

GBP

Some respite for the floundering Pound as the UK construction PMI returns to growth and beats consensus to break the recent run of disappointing macro leads. Cable has bounced firmly above 1.3600, to just over 1.3650 and Eur/Gbp is back below 0.8800, but Sterling is far from out of the firing line amidst yet more Brexit-related political divisions and uncertainty over the EU withdrawal bill on customs union and Irish border dispute among other contentious issues.

EUR

Pivoting around the 1.2000 marker vs the Usd having traded below the 200 DMA for the first time in around 12 months yesterday, and the headline pair now looking prone to more downside if that key technical level fails to hold (1.2016).

CAD

The Loonie has resumed its overall recovery from recent 1.2900 and above lows vs the Usd in wake of Tuesday’s better than forecast Canadian GDP report, with more impetus emanating from a more confident if not hawkish BoC Governor Poloz. Usd/Cad is now looking at more bids said to be sitting between 1.2820-00.

JPY/CHF

Both sitting pretty tight vs the buck having just survived tests of notable levels that could have accelerated recent losses on breaks of 110.00 and parity respectively.

FIXED INCOME

Don’t fight the Fed springs to mind given negative price action in bonds, but Gilts have independent catalysts behind the deeper downturn to a 121.82 Liffe low (-62 ticks vs -13 ticks at best) following a much better than anticipated rebound in the UK construction PMI and recent marked outperformance vs peers. Bunds have also extended losses, to 30 ticks at 158.44, in wake of firmer than forecast Eurozone manufacturing PMIs and GDP data overall, along with a somewhat mixed German 5 year tap. Meanwhile, US Treasuries remain on the defensive ahead of the aforementioned FOMC, but perhaps just as cautious if not more apprehensive in advance of the refunding announcement. The 10 year yield is inching closer to 3%, with 30 years just above 3.15% and 2 year cash over 2.51%.

COMMODITIES

In the commodities complex, crude fails to remain supported by ongoing speculation that the US could withdraw from the Iranian nuclear deal. Tuesday's API report revealed an increase 3.4mln in crude inventories, 0.7mln build in Cushing, Gasoline build by 1.6mln and showing a draw in distillates of 4.0mln .  In the metals sector, Gold is also sitting in positive territory in the context of a falling Dollar. Copper has also bounced from a monthly low following Chinese manufacturing sector data that suggested improving domestic demand in China.

US API weekly Crude Stocks (27 Apr) +3.427M vs. Exp. +0.700M (Prev. 1.099M). (Newswires)

IMF official says Saudi Arabia needs oil at USD 85-87/bbl to balance budget. (Newswires)

Russian oil production in April in line with May at 10.97mln BPD. (Newswires)

 

US

US Special Counsel Mueller suggested the possibility of a subpoena to Trump's lawyers during a meeting in March if US President Trump declines to speak with investigators in Russia investigation. (Washington Post)

Apple (AAPL) reported an EPS of USD 2.73, higher than the expected USD 2.69, revenue was a touch light coming in at 61.14bln against expected USD 61.2bln. However shares surged after market following the announcement of USD 100bln share repurchase programme and a dividend increase of 16%. In terms of unit sales, iPhone sales were a slight miss at 52.2mln, against the expected 53mln whilst iPads and Macs modestly exceeded expectations. Apple traded higher after market by as much as 5%.

content: Gilts and Short Sterling continue to unwind recent gains on the back of the much improved construction PMI that has also helped the Pound claw back a chunk of its losses in FX circles. The 10 year bond just slipped a bit further below the 122.00 level to 121.89 (-55 ticks), while the 3 month strip is now up to 3 ticks below parity. content:
EQUITIES

European markets have returned on an upbeat tone (Eurostoxx +0.5%) with all major bourses in the green following mass closures in the region yesterday. Germany’s DAX 30 is now outperforming its peers after breaching its 200DMA to the upside. All sectors are firmly in the green with outperformance in materials as miners are lifted amid higher copper prices. The tech sector is feeling a boost following Apple’s earnings post-market yesterday with the likes of Infineon (+3.4%) and STMicroelectronics (+3.7%) at the top of their respective indices. On the downside, earnings dampened the likes of Paddy Power Betfair (-6.3%), Swisscom (-4.3%) and Direct Line Insurance (-3.8%).

content: The Short Sterling strip is narrowly mixed and the curve marginally steeper in wake of the latest weaker than forecast UK release that has almost wiped out market pricing for a BoE rate hike this month. However, Gilts are on the defensive and underperforming in consolidative and corrective trade ahead of today’s construction PMI, and the Fed, with the former expected to reclaim 50+ status, albeit just following the collapse in March amidst inclement weather. The early Liffe range for the 10 year debt future is 122.12-31 vs Tuesday’s 122.44 settlement, with FTSE gains on FX grounds also an indirectly negative factor for Gilts.

content: The 10 year German benchmark has returned to the fray after May Day on a softer footing in line with weaker US Treasuries in the run up to the FOMC as the corresponding T-note yield creeps back up towards the 3% level. Bunds are also braced for the ‘full’ set of Eurozone manufacturing PMIs and preliminary Q1 GDP data ahead of Eur3 bn Bobl supply, as 5 year cash trades just above -0.05% and the future hovers a few ticks shy of 131.00 within a 131.02-130.96 range vs 158.70-158.54 for the 10 year bond compared to Monday’s 158.74 close.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
2nd May 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia equity markets eventually saw a broad risk-averse tone despite initially trading mixed throughout most the session following a similar close on Wall St. where stocks rebounded from the initial data-triggered selling pressure and the Nasdaq outperformed in anticipation of Apple earnings. The tech giant eventually reported a beat on EPS, announced a USD 100bln share repurchase authorization and raised dividends by 16%, although it slightly missed on revenue and iPhone sales; shares were higher by around 5% after-market which fuelled further upside in Nasdaq 100 futures to above 6700. US equity futures have since pulled-back from highs amid a bout of selling following reports that Special Counsel Mueller suggested the possibility of a subpoena if President Trump refuses to speak to investigators, although the pressure was suppressed shortly after it was determined this was from a meeting with Trump lawyers back in March. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) traded mixed as earnings dictated price action. Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) and Hang Seng (-0.6%) traded subdued despite initial gains in mainland on return from the extended weekend as it took its first opportunity to react to better than expected Chinese Official Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMI data. However, the picture then gradually deteriorated following the Caixin Manufacturing PMI which also topped estimates but showed Export Orders shrank for the first time since November 2016. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful amid similar price action in T-notes and as stocks took much of the focus, while the results of an enhanced-liquidity for 2yr-20yr also failed to spur demand.

FTSE

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – Vague takeover chatter was noted yesterday, with Roche (ROG SW) as a potential acquirer; unconfirmed. (Newswires) 

Sainsbury’s (SBRY LN) – The chief executive of the co. has rebuked claims that the proposed merger with Asda will be negative for suppliers and would lead to higher costs for customers. (Times)

Glencore (GLEN LN) – Co. won a temporary injunction of over USD 2.8bln of royalties against sanctioned Israeli Businessman Dan Gertler which he claims he is owed from the miner in the Democratic Republic of Congo. (FT)

Standard Chartered (STAN LN) - Q1 Adj. pre-tax profit USD 1.26bln vs. Exp. USD 1.30bln, operating income USD 3.87bln vs. Exp. USD 3.90bln. (Newswires)

DAX

Adidas (ADS GY) - Under Armour Inc (UAA) reported Q1 EPS USD 0.00 vs. Exp. USD -0.05, revenue USD 1.20bln vs. Exp. USD 1.12bln. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Co. shareholders have been recommended by proxy adviser Glass Lewis to vote against ratifying the actions of management and supervisory boards at the lender’s 2018 annual general meeting in May. (Newswires)

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) - Volkswagen of America reports +4.5% sales at 28,794 units. (Newswires)

BMW (BMW GY) – BMW of North America report +4.2% sales in April at 27,213 units. Separately, the company is being vilified for not immediately acting over potentially fatal safety fears after being warned of these by a government agency, and only taking action after the death of a driver due to this. (Times/ Newswires).

Daimler (DAI GY) – Mercedes-Benz reports +1% sales in April at 27,207 units. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Hugo Boss (BOSS GY) – Q1 revenue EUR 650mln vs. Exp. EUR 654mln, adj. EBITDA EUR 99mln vs. Exp. EUR 95.2mln and affirms FY outlook. (Newswires)

CAC

Sanofi (SAN FP) – Co. and US based Regeneron (REGN) are to lower the net price of PRALUENT (alirocumab) injection for in return for more affordable and straightforward patient access for express script patients. (Newswires)

Schneider Electric (SU FP) - India’s Larsen and Toubro has agreed to sell its electrical and automation business for USD 2.1bln to Schneider Electric. (Newswires)

Vivendi (VIV FP) – The co.’s board has said that it will examine various scenarios including an IPO regarding the capital evolution of its Universal Music Group (UMG) branch. (Newswires)

Lagardére (MMB FP) – The co. has been targeted by an activist fund which is pushing for a governance change. (FT)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

EDF (EDF FP) – Co. has interviewed a minimum of five investment banks for advice on a potential sale of 20% to 29% stake in its fleet of operating 9GW nuclear plants in the UK. (Newswires)

PAN EUROPE

Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM) - US auto sales +4.5% vs. Exp. -1.4%. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PHILIPS LIGHTING (LIGHT NA) UPGRADED TO EQUAL WEIGHT FROM UNDERWEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

SCANDINAVIA

Lundin Petroleum (LUPE SS) – Revenue in Q1 at USD 692mln vs. Exp USD 541mln and EBITDA at USD 456.5mln vs Exp. USD 433mln. Net result at USD 228.8mln vs. Exp. 243mln. (Newswires)

Novo Nordisk (NOVOB DC) – Q1 sales DKK 26.9bln vs. Exp. DKK 26.7bln. Q1 EBIT DKK 12.4bln vs. Exp. DKK 11.8bln. Q1 net profit DKK 10.8bln vs. Exp. DKK 10.1bln. Co. says 2018 sales growth is now expected to be 3% to 5% vs. Prev. 2% to 5% (measured in local currency). Co. says 2018 operating profit growth is now expected to be 2% to 5% vs. Prev. 1% to 5%. (Newswires)

GN Store (GN DC) – Q1 revenue DKK 2.3bln vs. Exp. DKK 2.43bln and EBITA DKK 126mln vs. Prev. DKK 103mln. (Newswires)

SMI

Swisscom (SCMN SW) – The co. reports a revenue of CHF 2.89bln vs. Exp. CHF 2.83bln and an EBITDA of CHF 1.058bln vs. Exp CHF 1.05bln. The FY outlook is unchanged. (Newswires)

Novartis (NOVN SW) –Co.’s cell therapy Kymriah has been approve by US regulators for patients suffering from a second type of blood cancer, large B-cell lymphoma, that has worsened despite two or more earlier lines of therapy. (Newswires)

US

SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals: -0.95%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: +0.11%, Energy: -0.85%, Financials: -0.08%, Health Care: -0.21%, Industrials: -0.63%, Materials: -0.22%, Technology: +1.22%, Telecoms: -1.10%, Utilities: -0.48%.

Volume was thinner with European traders away for Labour Day, but even so, there was a familiar, horizontal pattern for equities, with the SPX continuing to dance between its 50 dma and 200 dma, however in late afternoon trade we did see a turnaround.

In terms of unit sales, iPhone sales were a slight miss at 52.2mln, against the expected 53mln whilst iPads and Macs modestly exceeded expectations. Apple traded higher after market by as much as 5%.

DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: US equity futures initially lifted by Apple earnings (outperformance in the Nasdaq 100) before gains were trimmed amid latest Trump/Mueller developments
content:
• US equity futures initially lifted by Apple earnings (outperformance in the Nasdaq 100) before gains were trimmed amid latest Trump/Mueller developments
  • DXY took a breather from yesterday’s advances but remained above the 92.00 level. EUR/USD and GBP/USD just about held on to the 1.2000 and 1.3600 handles respectively
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ mfg PMIs, UK construction PMI, EZ GDP, US ADP, FOMC, DoEs, US refunding and a slew of speakers

HIGHLIGHTS FROM YESTERDAY/LATE MONDAY FOR EU PARTICIPANTS

Italian President Mattarella has ruled out new elections in June, following the news on Monday that Italy's 5 Star Movement leader Di Maio called for early elections. (Messaggero)

UK Markit/CIPS Manufacturing PMI (Apr) 53.9 vs. Exp. 54.8 (Prev. 55.1, Rev. 54.9) (Newswires)

UK PM May is reported to be mulling a deal with Brussels that Brexiteers fear could result to 'EU Mark II' and make the UK take rules from EU. May has informed ministers that the UK could “potentially” accept an association agreement with the EU, which critics say would make Britain a “rule taker” from Europe (Telegraph) Similar reports suggest that the UK are set to unveil a new proposal to the EU and attempt to overcome the Irish border issue as negotiations resume once again this week.

US President Trump effectively extended tariff relief for EU and other allies for a month to June 1st and is said to finalize agreement to exempt South Korea on steel. The reports stated that US delayed the deadline for decision for EU, Canada and Mexico, while US reached agreements in principle regarding tariffs with Argentina, Australia and Brazil. (WSJ)

Australian RBA Cash Rate (May) 1.50% vs. Exp. 1.50% (Prev. 1.50%). (Newswires) RBA reiterates that steady policy is consistent with growth and inflation targets, while it also repeated that low rates supports the domestic economy and that a stronger AUD would slow economic pick-up. Furthermore, RBA stated that Inflation and wage growth likely to stay low for a while but added that it expects stronger exports.

Israel PM Netanyahu said Iran has been hiding nuclear weapons activity and that Israel can provide "new and conclusive proof" of this, while Netanyahu was also said to seek a vote to enable the Defence Minister to decide on war in extreme circumstances. (Newswires) Iran denied these allegations while the Iranian Foreign Minister tweeted that allegations are old and have already been dealt with by the IAEA. Furthermore, Israeli PM Netanyahu says no one is seeking a war with Iran (Twitter/CNN)

US ISM Manufacturing PMI (Apr) 57.3 vs. Exp. 58.4 (Prev. 59.3) (Newswires)

US ISM Manufacturing Prices Paid (Apr) 79.3 vs. Exp. 78.3 (Prev. 78.1)

US ISM Manufacturing New Orders Index (Apr) 61.2 (Prev. 61.9)

US ISM Manufacturing Employment Index (Apr) 54.2 vs. Exp. 57.0 (Prev. 57.3)

US Construction Spending MM (Mar) -1.7% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.1%, Rev. 1.0%)

The tech giant eventually reported a beat on EPS, announced a USD 100bln share repurchase authorization and raised dividends by 16%, although it slightly missed on revenue and iPhone sales; shares were higher by around 5% after-market which fuelled further upside in Nasdaq 100 futures to above 6700. US equity futures have since pulled-back from highs amid a bout of selling following reports that Special Counsel Mueller suggested the possibility of a subpoena if President Trump refuses to speak to investigators, although the pressure was suppressed shortly after it was determined this was from a meeting with Trump lawyers back in March. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) traded mixed as earnings dictated price action. Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) and Hang Seng (-0.6%) traded subdued despite initial gains in mainland on return from the extended weekend as it took its first opportunity to react to better than expected Chinese Official Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMI data. However, the picture then gradually deteriorated following the Caixin Manufacturing PMI which also topped estimates but showed Export Orders shrank for the first time since November 2016. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful amid similar price action in T-notes and as stocks took much of the focus, while the results of an enhanced-liquidity for 2yr-20yr also failed to spur demand.

PBoC injected CNY 200bln via 7-day reverse repos for a net neutral position due to maturing repos. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3670 (Prev. 6.3393); weakest fix since January 25th.

UK/EU

UK PM May is expected to back EU ‘customs partnership’, according to press reports. (FT) However, there were separate reports that UK PM May was warned by 60 Conservative MPs a post-Brexit customs partnership with the EU will result to a collapse of the government. (Telegraph)

UK Brexit Secretary Davis said draft withdrawal text should be available by October, while Davis added that transition period is not up for further negotiation and that future trade agreement must be 'nailed down' before transition starts. (Newswires)

UK BRC Shop Price Index (Apr) Y/Y -1.0% (Prev. -1.0%). (Newswires)

FX

The DXY took a breather from yesterday’s advances but remained above the 92.00 level. This provided mild respite for its major counterparts with EUR/USD and GBP/USD just about holding on to the 1.2000 and 1.3600 handles respectively, while the PBoC also adjusted its CNY reference rate to the weakest since January in response to the recent USD advances. Elsewhere, USD/JPY slightly pulled back ahead of the 110.00 level and on the suggested Trump subpoena reports, NZD was choppy around 0.7000 following mixed jobs data, while CAD outperformed in the wake of firmer than expected GDP data and hawkish rhetoric from BoC Governor Poloz.

New Zealand Employment Change (Q1) Q/Q 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.5%). (Newswires)
New Zealand Employment Change (Q1) Y/Y 3.1% vs. Exp. 3.3% (Prev. 3.7%)
New Zealand Unemployment Rate (Q1) 4.4% vs. Exp. 4.4% (Prev. 4.5%)

BoC’s Poloz reiterated higher rates are warranted over time but some accommodation will still be required, while he also repeated the BoC will proceed cautiously and be guided by incoming data. Furthermore, Poloz added that concern is that interest rates are really low and can't be described as neutral, while he also stated expect sentiment to improve if NAFTA gets resolved but need to wait and see data before changing inflation outlook. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES 

Commodities found reprieve overnight and nursed some of the prior day’s losses across the complex which were attributed to the advances seen in the greenback. As such, WTI crude futures were mildly higher overnight and back above the USD 67/bbl with a larger than expected build in API crude inventories largely ignored amid fatigue following the prior day’s descent. Elsewhere, short covering was observed in gold as the USD pared some gains and amid an eventual broad-risk averse tone in the region, while copper was also higher with prices supported after its largest consumer China returned from the extended weekend.

US API weekly Crude Stocks (27 Apr) +3.427M vs. Exp. +0.700M (Prev. 1.099M). (Newswires)

US

As US traders returned to their desk following a relatively rangebound overnight session, Treasuries sold-off just before the cash-equity open, as the Greenback strengthened. The yield curve bear-steepened on Tuesday with the 30yr yields higher by c.4bps whilst the 2yr higher by c.2.5bps at settlement. Most of the action was seen in the long-end of the curve, however, despite the bear-steepening, 2s30s and 5s30s modestly narrowed by around 1bps. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 8 ticks lower at 119-12.

US Special Counsel Mueller suggested the possibility of a subpoena to Trump's lawyers during a meeting in March if US President Trump declines to speak with investigators in Russia investigation. (Washington Post)

US Trade Representative Lighthizer said he has no idea when we will have a NAFTA deal but added that he would like one within two weeks after the May meeting, while he also noted the tariff issues goes hand in hand with NAFTA negotiations. Lighthizer also said trade deficits do matter and that the US is making progress with EU on metal duties. (Newswires)

White House Trade Advisor Navarro said tariff relief will not be extended again for Canada and Mexico, while he also said all countries which were exempted from steel and aluminium tariffs would still face restrictions including import quotas. (Newswires)

Mexico’s Economy Minister Guajardo said that Mexico will apply reciprocal measures to any metal tariffs from the US and that the country will make sure it is not used as a back door to any nations who want to skirt US tariffs, while Canada's Foreign Minister Freeland said US metal tariffs will hurt US jobs as well as Canada's and reiterated that NAFTA and tariffs are separate issues, while she also noted good progress on auto content rules. (Newswires)

Apple (AAPL) reported an EPS of USD 2.73, higher than the expected USD 2.69, revenue was a touch light coming in at 61.14bln against expected USD 61.2bln. However shares surged after market following the announcement of USD 100bln share repurchase programme and a dividend increase of 16%. In terms of unit sales, iPhone sales were a slight miss at 52.2mln, against the expected 53mln whilst iPads and Macs modestly exceeded expectations. Apple traded higher after market by as much as 5%.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks trade mixed as region digests earnings including Apple's results
content:
Asia equity markets trade somewhat mixed following a similar close on Wall St. where stocks rebounded from the initial data-triggered selling pressure and the Nasdaq outperformed in anticipation of Apple earnings. The tech giant eventually reported a beat on EPS, announced a USD 100bln share repurchase authorization and raised dividends by 16%, although it slightly missed on revenue and iPhone sales. Nonetheless, the buyback announcement was the determining factor and Apple shares were higher by around 5% after-market which fuelled further upside in Nasdaq 100 futures to above 6700. US equity futures have since pulled-back from highs amid a bout of selling following reports that Special Counsel Mueller suggested the possibility of a subpoena if President Trump refuses to speak to investigators, although the pressure was suppressed shortly after it was determined this was from a meeting with Trump lawyers back in March. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) are mixed as earnings dictates price action with Japan Tobacco and Qantas among the leaders in their respective markets after the announcement of their results. Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) and Hang Seng (-0.6%) are also varied with the mainland just about keeping afloat on return from the extended weekend as it takes its first opportunity to react to better than expected Chinese Official Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMI data, which was also followed up by Caixin Manufacturing PMI topping estimates but showed Export Orders shrank for the first time since November 2016.

In FX markets, the DXY took a breather from yesterday’s advances but remains above the 92.00 level. This has provided only mild respite for its major counterparts with EUR/USD and GBP/USD just about holding on to the 1.2000 and 1.3600 handles respectively, while the PBoC also adjusted its CNY reference rate to the weakest since January in response to the recent USD advances. Elsewhere, USD/JPY slightly pulled back ahead of the 110.00 level and on the suggested Trump subpoena reports, while NZD is choppy around 0.7000 following mixed jobs data.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are uneventful amid similar price action in T-notes and with stocks taking much of the focus, while participants also await the results of an enhanced-liquidity auction later.
